Coastal locations prone to flooding. For a case study of a storm event in December 2013, we found that all models over-predicted flood extents, but the machine learning model was closest to the observed extents.

Introduction

Climate change-driven global sea-level rise increases the risk of coastal flooding through higher return frequencies of coastal water levels during storms. Although the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fifth Assessment Report found limited evidence for an increase in storminess due to climate change, measurable regional rises in mean sea level have already led to increases in the frequency of inundation (IPCC 2014). The most recent climate change risk assessment for the UK projects that winter weather will be dominated by more mobile cyclonic systems, which cause coastal flooding, exacerbated by 5-10cm higher rises in sea levels than previously projected (Betts, Pearson 2021).

Coastal flooding is a significant climate change concern for both societal and economic impacts. A substantial fraction of global infrastructure (power plants, ports, housing, roads, and rail) is located at the coast, and a combination of sea-level rise, changes in storm surge intensity, and land subsidence, combined with economic growth, pose immense threats to coastal and low-lying communities (Oddo et al. 2020). There is a demand for better quantification of coastal flood risk for current and future climates across multiple industries and the public sector.

Coastal flood risk quantification poses numerous challenges, including substantial modeling uncertainties and the computational intensity of physical simulation models for storm surge and inundation, which limit both the resolution and extent over which they can be applied. In this paper, we address the latter component and consider the suitability of computationally "lightweight" approaches to derive inundation from water levels and geospatial features for coastal flood risk mapping at the country scale, a particular requirement for industry sectors such as transport, energy, and utilities that operate across large geographic domains.

The increase in data availability in the field of environmental sciences has led to the emergence of data-driven models to represent complex physical processes. Studies have recently shown the use of machine learning (ML) techniques to evaluate the flood susceptibility of an area. However, studies so far have mainly focused on fluvial and pluvial flooding rather than coastal flooding and have been limited to smaller regions (Tehrany et al. 2014; Chen et al. 2020; Avand et al. 2021).

The aim of this paper is to derive a machine learning model for coastal flood mapping using historical flood records in England. The model will be tested on the December 2013 Storm Xavier event and compared to a static inundation model to understand the relative strengths and weaknesses of each approach. Our work will contribute to improved coastal flood risk quantification and climate change resilience across multiple impacted sectors.

2 Data and methods

The aim of this study is to use a data-driven approach to estimate the extents of coastal flooding. The methodology is summarized in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Methodology

2.1 Datasets

The variables used in this study to predict coastal flooding include elevation, slope, aspect, topographic wetness index (TWI), land cover, sea surface height (SSH), and distance to the coast. The elevation, slope, aspect, TWI, and land cover variables were selected based on a literature review of flood susceptibility (Avand et al. 2021; Park, Lee 2020). Past studies mainly focused on fluvial and pluvial flooding and included variables such as distance to river and rainfall (Avand et al. 2021). As the focus is on coastal flooding, the choice of using distance to coast and SSH is most suitable.

A historical record of flooding (Environment Agency 2018) was used to generate flooded and non-flooded points (5099 points each) as labeling data for the ML model. A description of the variables and preprocessing steps are included in Appendix A.

2.2 Methodology

The flooded and non-flooded points were combined into a dataset sorted by date with a 1 assigned to flooded points and 0 to non-flooded points. For each point (day, longitude, latitude), the corresponding elevation, slope, aspect, TWI, nearest SSH, distance to coast, and land cover were assigned. The land cover was encoded using One-Hot encoding. The dataset was split temporally into training and testing, with the first 70% of the dataset used for training and the last 30% used for testing.
